Legal_Issue: Application of 'physical presence' test without prior notice
Application_Facts: Applicant was 255 days short of the required physical presence in Canada
Court_Ruling: Case remanded for redetermination with clear notice of the test to be applied
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship Judge applied 'physical presence' test without notifying applicant
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of prior notice on applicable legal test
Assessment_Factor: Choice and notification of residency test
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide adequate procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Residency records, duration of stay in Canada
Application_Basis: Physical presence, centralized mode of living, Koo test
Evidence_Assessed: Duration and pattern of physical presence in Canada
Relief_Sought: Grant of citizenship or fair reassessment
Governing_Rule: Judges may apply any of the three residency tests but must provide prior notice
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clarity on which test would be used
Harm_Assessment: Potential denial of citizenship due to unfair process
Cause_Description: Insufficient physical presence and unclear judicial test application
Evidence_Handling: Residency evidence considered under incorrect procedural framework
Legal_Provision_Violated: Principles of natural justice under statutory interpretation
Evidence_Issues: No dispute over factual evidence, issue lies in legal interpretation and notice
Evidence_Assessment: Residency duration assessed but without proper procedural context
Decision_Rationale: Need for fairness and transparency in applying legal tests
Evidentiary_Issues: Absence of notice affected evidentiary preparation
